Play this after Half-Life but before Opposing Force. It's quite good, actually, although it is certainly less ambitious than Opposing Force (being half the length and with no new weapons). The puzzles and environments are great, being like Half-Life's while also feeling fresh and new. You get to see different parts of Black Mesa here, parts that are perhaps less exciting and certainly less varied but no less interesting. The Xen section of this game is also quite a bit better (and shorter obviously) than the Xen section of Half-Life, and I think it was actually the best part of the game for me. You definitely don't have to play this game to understand the rest of the story of the Half-Life series (and both this game and Opposing Force have questionable canonicity) but if you are a fan of the series I don't see why you wouldn't want to have a fun, short, interesting extension of the setting of Half-Life.

Like Opposing Force, Blue Shift offers a different perspective of the events of the first Half Life game. You play as Barney Calhoun, a Black Mesa security guard who is on duty when everything goes to shambles. Barney must then help a group of scientists with finding a way to escape by traversing the less traveled paths of Black Mesa.

Blue Shift is fairly straightforward in its presentation, but its charm comes from the story and the vulnerability of your character, which heightens the experience. Barney isn't equipped with military style weaponry or a HEV suit, instead relying on armor pieces he finds rather than HEV armor panels. Blue Shift isn't terribly difficult unlike the others, but experiencing an alien invasion as a vulnerable average joe is expertly demonstrated. 

The story also deserves praise for its different approach. If Half Life is a tale of survival and endurance, and Opposing Force is a tale of betrayal and redemption, then Blue Shift is a tale of cooperation and human decency.  Dr. Rosenberg and his colleagues use scientific methods and advanced technolgies to find various ways to escape, but none of that woud be possible without Barney's bravery and dilligence in fighting the aliens and reparing old tech in decrepid, dim areas of Black Mesa. Trapped in a facility with aliens and the military around every corner, both groups push to accomplish their goals together for the sole purpose of saving each other from a terrible death. 

This is what makes Blue Shift a memorable experience. It is short and straightforward, and may not be as groundbreaking or innovative as Half Life or Opposing Force, but for some games, it's all you need.

According to the Half-Life Wiki, a lot of people were really down on Blue Shift because it didn't add any new weapons or enemies like Opposing Force did.  Indeed, many features from the base Half-Life game are missing from this expansion.  I think they're being a little unfair.  Opposing Force is a great expansion, but I think in-between that and Blue Shift Gearbox learned a lot about the essential feel of Half-Life, and the result made me think of an old cliche: Less is more.

I really like how this expansion explores the Black Mesa crisis from a totally different angle.  You play as a security guard, rather than a scientist, and explore the life of Barney Calhoun as he attempts to protect the personnel from violent aliens and a military cover-up operation.  Unlike Gordon Freeman, or indeed Adrian Shephard from Opposing Force, you don't get access to god weapons or powered armor; you're just a security guard.  That changes the entire way that Half-Life feels without fundamentally changing the gameplay all that much.  Some of the new puzzles were actually real head-scratchers for me, but you can rest assured that if you pay attention you'll rarely if ever need to consult a walkthrough.

It's pretty obvious to me that Gearbox really tried to make a game the same way Valve makes them, unlike in Opposing Force where they changed almost everything.  To give one example, there's a puzzle where you have to drain a pool of toxic liquid so that you can rearrange some barrels so that when you refill the pool they'll float up and make a bridge.  It's not executed perfectly, but you can really see the effort.  It earns big points from me.  Even the Xen levels are more tolerable than they are in Half-Life, because they're less tedious and give you more time to come to grips with the new environment.

Towards the midpoint of the game you meet up with a scientist named Doctor Rosenberg and accompany him to an older area of the Black Mesa facility where you have to help him get an older version of the teleporter working.  I think this is the point where a lot of things really started to click for me, because here the game starts to feel a lot like an old science fiction movie, with old-fashioned computers making bleeping noises and a loud-mouthed scientist muttering technobabble at you.  You even have to fiddle with some of the machinery while defending the lab from hostiles at one point.  This really ticks a lot of boxes for me.

I tried to keep this review short, but I find that I have a lot to praise about Blue Shift.  I went into this expecting a pretty lackluster experience, but I came out of it actually really liking it.  Sure it's shorter than Half-Life, and arguably there's less stuff in it, but I felt that most of it was used to great effect, and I can safely say I was pleasantly surprised.  Sometimes, every once in a while, less really is more.

Like Opposing Force before it, Blue Shift is an expansion for Half-Life that maintains the gameplay of the original game. Unlike Opposing Force, Blue Shift adds almost nothing to the game. Neither weapons nor enemies, at least; just a short campaign (between 4 and 5 hours).

However, it doesn't mean the game is bad. It's still Half-Life and, therefore, remains a great FPS. Just keep in mind what you are buying: a short campaign, with much less content than the original game.

This expansion shows the events at Black Mesa through the point of view of one of its security guards. The gameplay, as said before, is identical to the original game, although it has fewer weapons, enemies, and is even easier. The interesting thing is that armor is no longer recharged at electrical terminals; instead, you must find helmets and vests scattered throughout the game, which fits your role perfectly.

Overall, I recommend buying this game, but keep in mind that it's quite short.

Half-Life: Blue Shift - Является хоть и коротким, но зато интересным и достойным дополнением к оригиналу. Играем мы за опытного охранника научно-исследовательского комплекса под названием Black Mesa, зовут его Барни Калхаун, и ему предстоит не менее сложный путь, чтобы спастись. Меня очень удивил тот факт что Valve ещё в те времена, реализовали вселенную, где все события происходят в одно и то же время, что и в оригинале игры Half-Life, в начале игры тут мы можем увидеть Гордона Фримена, передвигающегося на монорельсе, это очень круто! Сюжет не менее интересный, нам предстоит не легкий путь чтобы пройти игру, воевать с военными и с всеми нами знакомыми пришельцами. Рекомендую пройти игру каждому, особенно фанатам.
